**The US government is increasingly likely to shut down next week. Here's why.**
The U.S. federal government is on track to shut down next week because Republicans and Democrats have failed to agree on a funding plan before the current appropriations expire on September 30, 2025. Republicans control the House, Senate and presidency, but in the Senate most major bills require 60 votes to overcome the filibuster; with only 53 Republican senators, they need Democratic support to pass a funding bill. Both parties want a short‑term “continuing resolution” to buy time for a full budget, yet they remain at an impasse. Democrats, under pressure from their base, are using the stalemate to extract concessions, while Republicans—including President Donald Trump—have refused to negotiate. The Democratic bill would fund the government through October 31 and includes provisions Republicans are unlikely to accept, such as reversing Medicaid cuts from the ‘Big Beautiful Bill’ and permanently extending subsidies for the Affordable Care Act. If those cuts and subsidy reversals go through, millions of Americans could lose health coverage.

The GOP bill passed the House largely along party lines but stalled in the Senate, failing to reach the 60‑vote threshold. The Democratic bill only received a Senate vote and also failed.

If a shutdown occurs, mandatory‑spending programs (Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid) will continue, but most federal employees will not be paid until the shutdown ends, and some may be furloughed. The Trump administration has warned of potential mass firings, while some Democrats dismiss the threat as intimidation. National parks, museums, and air‑traffic control could be shut down or delayed, and the Congressional Budget Office estimates that a five‑week shutdown in 2019 reduced real GDP by $3 billion.
